unnormalised: Okay, so you're planning a trip within India, huh? Awesome! Forget those pricey flights for a bit. Let's talk local transport and road trips – the real heart of exploring our amazing country. I mean, sure, flying from Delhi to Mumbai in 2 hrs is convenient, but what about the experiences you miss?
normalised: Okay, so you're planning a trip within India, huh? Awesome! Forget those pricey flights for a bit. Let's talk local transport and road trips – the real heart of exploring our amazing country. I mean, sure, flying from Delhi to Mumbai in two hours is convenient, but what about the experiences you miss?

unnormalised: First off, let's acknowledge the king of Indian roads: the auto-rickshaw. In cities like Chennai and Bangalore, autos are everywhere. Bargain hard though! A ride that *should* cost Rs. 80 can easily become Rs. 150 if you’re not careful. And always, ALWAYS, agree on the fare *before* you get in. Trust me on this one.
normalised: First off, let's acknowledge the king of Indian roads: the auto-rickshaw. In cities like Chennai and Bangalore, autos are everywhere. Bargain hard though! A ride that *should* cost rupee eighty can easily become rupee one hundred and fifty if you’re not careful. And always, ALWAYS, agree on the fare *before* you get in. Trust me on this one.

unnormalised: Then there's the bus. State transport buses, especially in places like Kerala and Himachal Pradesh, are lifelines. They might not be the comfiest (think bumpy rides and questionable hygiene), but they’re cheap, reliable (mostly!), and take you to some seriously remote spots. Fares can be as low as ₹5 per km. Just be prepared for some interesting characters and maybe a chicken or two sharing your seat!

They might not be the comfiest (think bumpy rides and questionable hygiene), but they’re cheap, reliable (mostly!), and take you to some seriously remote spots. Fares can be as low as rupee five per kilometer. Just be prepared for some interesting characters and maybe a chicken or two sharing your seat!

unnormalised: Now, for road trips! Ah, the open road. If you're feeling adventurous, rent a car or even a Royal Enfield and hit the highways. Remember to keep your driver's license (DL) and vehicle registration handy. National Highway 44 (NH44), connecting Kashmir to Kanyakumari, is an epic route, but be prepared for varying road conditions. Stop at dhabas along the way for authentic local food – you *have* to try the parathas at Murthal, Haryana!
normalised: Now, for road trips! Ah, the open road. If you're feeling adventurous, rent a car or even a Royal Enfield and hit the highways. Remember to keep your driver's license (D-L) and vehicle registration handy. National Highway forty four (N-H forty four), connecting Kashmir to Kanyakumari, is an epic route, but be prepared for varying road conditions. Stop at dhabas along the way for authentic local food – you *have* to try the parathas at Murthal, Haryana!

unnormalised: Planning a road trip? Get your car serviced! A breakdown in the middle of nowhere is no fun. And download offline maps – mobile network coverage can be patchy in some areas. Also, pack essentials: water, snacks (especially those yummy Indian sweets), a first-aid kit, and maybe a power bank to charge your mobile. I always carry at least 2 ltrs of water per person per day.

I always carry at least two liters of water per person per day.

unnormalised: Don't forget to factor in travel time. Google Maps estimates are often… optimistic. Add at least 30% extra time, especially if you’re driving through congested city centres like Delhi or Kolkata. Traffic jams are a national sport, it seems.

unnormalised: Consider trains too! India has one of the largest railway networks in the world. Traveling by train is a great way to see the countryside and meet people. Book tickets in advance, especially during peak season (Diwali, Holi, etc.). A sleeper class ticket from Mumbai to Goa might cost around Rs. 800, but the experience is priceless. Try and book 3AC for a bit more comfort.
normalised: Consider trains too! India has one of the largest railway networks in the world. Traveling by train is a great way to see the countryside and meet people. Book tickets in advance, especially during peak season (Diwali, Holi, etc.). A sleeper class ticket from Mumbai to Goa might cost around rupee eight hundred, but the experience is priceless. Try and book three A-C for a bit more comfort.

unnormalised: Local trains are a different beast altogether. Mumbai's local trains are legendary – crowded, chaotic, but incredibly efficient. If you're visiting Mumbai, experience it at least once (during off-peak hours, if possible!). A single journey from Churchgate to Dadar will set you back just Rs. 10, but be prepared to be squished!

If you're visiting Mumbai, experience it at least once (during off-peak hours, if possible!). A single journey from Churchgate to Dadar will set you back just rupee ten, but be prepared to be squished!

unnormalised: Uber and Ola are lifesavers in most major cities, but remember surge pricing! On a rainy day in Bangalore, a ride that usually costs Rs. 200 can easily jump to Rs. 500. Plan accordingly. Consider using Rapido (bike taxis) for shorter distances – they're often cheaper and faster.
normalised: Uber and Ola are lifesavers in most major cities, but remember surge pricing! On a rainy day in Bangalore, a ride that usually costs rupee two hundred can easily jump to rupee five hundred. Plan accordingly. Consider using Rapido (bike taxis) for shorter distances – they're often cheaper and faster.

unnormalised: So, ditch the tourist traps and embrace the adventure of local transport. You'll discover hidden gems, meet incredible people, and create memories that will last a lifetime. Just remember to stay safe, be respectful, and bargain hard! Happy travels! And share your travel stories, I would love to hear them.
